Award.AwardTitle: New Econometric Approaches to Models with Unobserved Heterogeneity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops new methods for the statistical analysis of certain kinds of economic data. The first part of the research focuses on developing a new method for performing data analysis that requires less computational power than other competing methods. The result will speed data analysis for a class of problems in several different fields of economic analysis. The second part of the research considers a new method for using statistics to measure possible causal effects to measure treatment effects. The work will allow other researchers to improve empirical analysis in two different ways. Because computational costs are lower, researchers will be able to analyze larger data sets or consider larger and more realistic models. Second, the work will improve the methods empirical researchers use to test for causal effects. The PI plans to involve students in the research, and will make computer programs for the statistical methods available at no cost to the research community.

The research has two components. The first project develops a new statistically and computationally efficient method of estimation by simulation. Methods such as the method of simulated moments and indirect inference are widely used. However, when a finite number of simulation draws are used, these estimators are consistent but in general are not efficient. The new method will render these estimators efficient with as little as one simulation draw per observation. The second project considers issues of inference in instrumental variable models with heterogeneous treatment effects. In these cases, researchers interpret two stage least squares results as estimating local average treatment effects. While this interpretation is popular, it poses significant challenges. In particular, in these kinds of models one can no longer use the J-test of overidentifying restrictions to test the validity of exclusion restrictions. The project will develop a novel methodology for diagnostics of the exclusion restriction, a method motivated by ideas of subgroup robustness analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observed economic outcomes are greatly influenced by the unobserved differences between the economic agents (individuals, firms, states, etc.). For example, individuals vary widely in their preferences, endowments, and circumstances, all of which are at best partially observed by the researchers and policy makers. Such unobserved variation greatly complicates empirical analysis. This project developed several new practical solutions to the important associated problems that applied researchers in economics and other social sciences routinely encounter in their work.

First, the project developed valid inference procedures for models with heterogeneous treatment effects estimated by instrumental variables. Heterogeneity of treatment effects is widely acknowledged in economics, and instrumental variables approach is one of the most reliable and widespread ways of estimating causal effects using observational data. This project showed that the existing inference methods are not valid in such settings, and developed valid inference approaches for a range of instrumental variable regression estimators. In particular, new methods are valid in the so-called Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) settings and with possibly many instruments. Moreover, the project showed that there are two different and yet simultaneously valid ways of thinking about inference and sampling uncertainty in these settings, which result in two different (and yet both valid) asymptotic variance formulas and corresponding standard errors.

Second, the project considered the problem of estimation of economic models using simulation-based methods. The realism of modern structural economic models is often constrained by the computational complexity of their estimation. The project developed and studied the properties of new statistically and computationally efficient methods of estimation in such settings. These methods are shown to allow large savings in computation costs (in terms of time, energy, and the corresponding monetary costs). These methods also allow estimation of more accurate models of behavior of economic agents.

Third, the project developed a practical approach to estimation of a general class of semiparametric models when the data contains measurement errors. The new estimation method avoids the need for simulation or nonparametric estimation, which makes it particularly appealing and easy to use. The project also developed a practical solution to the long-standing problem of removing the bias of nonlinear panel data estimators in the presence of (possibly serially correlated) measurement errors in covariates. The project also developed robust and powerful (and yet simple to implement) inference procedures for these settings.

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2021
Modified by: Kirill Evdokimov
